question: Should you look at the title of a text to get an idea of the topic?
Should every story have a beginning, middle, and end?
Should pictures in a text help you understand the meaning?
Should skimming mean reading every word carefully?
Should scanning help you find specific information quickly?
Should a main idea tell what the whole text is about?
Should details in a text support the main idea?
Should headings and subheadings help organize information?
Should fiction texts always be true stories?
Should nonfiction texts give facts and information?
Should characters in a story always be real people?
Should you use context clues to figure out the meaning of new words?
Should the author’s purpose be the reason they wrote the text?
Should the author’s purpose always be to entertain?
Should the setting of a story describe where and when it happens?
Should the main character in a story always be perfect?
Should predicting while reading help you understand the text?
Should rereading a difficult part of the text help with comprehension?
Should you always understand a text the first time you read it?
Should bold and italic text sometimes show important words?
Should a glossary in a book explain word meanings?
Should the plot describe the events that happen in a story?
Should the problem in a story always be solved?
Should nonfiction texts sometimes include charts and diagrams?
Should a fable always include talking animals?
Should context clues always give the exact definition of a word?
Should summarizing mean retelling only the most important parts?
Should readers always agree with the author’s opinion?
Should illustrations sometimes explain things the text does not?
Should comparing and contrasting mean looking at similarities and differences?
